concept.title: Setting Trace Filters Tutorial
concept.shortdesc: Explains how to use the kernel trace tool API to filter trace data.

section.title: Purpose
section.p: Trace data is written to kernel side chunks. The kernel trace tool API can specify which trace data should be made available for further processing by setting filters.

section.title: Intended audience
section.p: This document is intended for third party developers writing a trace tool using the kernel trace tool component.

section.title: Required background
section.p: The trace filters defined in EUser. The kernel trace tool component in general.

section.title: Introduction
section.p: Setting trace filters is a short task which is performed in combination with related tasks as explained in Kernel Trace Tool Tutorial.

section.title: Using Kernel Trace tool to set trace filters
section.p: The following tasks will be covered in this tutorial:

section.title: Basic procedure
section.p: The high level steps to setting trace filters are shown here:

li.p: Set a primary filter specifying a category of data and whether it is to be output or not.
Set a secondary filter if necessary.

section.title: Using the API
section.p: These are the function calls required to

li.p: Call the SetFilter() function of the RBTrace object. This function takes two arguments:
An integer representing the trace category taken from the enumeration BTrace::TCategories, and
A boolean, True if the trace category is to be output and False if it is not.
If you need a secondary trace filter, call the SetFilter2() function of the RBTrace object.
